text: Theresa May now has only one graceful way out of this debacle: offer a timetable for her departure, to win over the 30-odd Tories who say they’d (then) vote for her deal. My column:
author: FraserNelson

author: FraserNelson

author: FraserNelson

text: As many as 30 Tories have made it clear (in private) that they'd vote for May's deal if she lays out a timetable for her departure. Resignation is the only card she has left. Will she play it? My @telegraph column: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/21/mrs-may-offering-quit-might-takes-get-deal-passed/ …

text: The EU’s short extension might lure Tories into thinking no-deal is more likely - making it harder for May to pass her deal. Meanwhile, parliament has more time to plot alternatives. My take:- https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/21/mrs-may-offering-quit-might-takes-get-deal-passed/ …
author: FraserNelson

text: Parliament has just been given more time to force Theresa May into a softer Brexit. My Daily Telegraph column on what happens now: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/21/mrs-may-offering-quit-might-takes-get-deal-passed/ …
author: FraserNelson

text: I think your examples (wasn't one of them c1700?) makes the case: modern treaties/deals, including almost all signed by EU, have exit clauses. They're standard. The WA falls short of this standard, hence the problems with parliament.
author: FraserNelson

text: and 1) violates the longstanding UK principle that no parliament can bind its successors. Yes, May erred in agreeing to something Parliament would not approve. Without an exit clause, the WA falls short of international norms. That's as much of the problem here as anything else.
author: FraserNelson

text: I pointed out that it's a three-way standoff. The EU was asked to compromise by Parliament, and refused. It's entitled to do so, but can't really act like a baffled onlooker. There is intransigence on all sides.
author: FraserNelson

text: Yes, I didn’t meant to suggest that all committed Brexiteers back the (awful) deal - just that many do. And it’s hard to say those who do back it are fainthearts or sellouts. A choice between principle or pragmatism: making a statement or effecting change. An unenviable choice...
author: FraserNelson

text: She’s right, it’s an excellent piece. Read it here: https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2019/03/no-matter-what-terrorists-say-islam-and-the-west-are-not-at-war/ …
author: FraserNelson

text: From David Davis to Matthew Elliot, the most committed Brexiteers are now ready to back May’s deal - seeing the alternative as delayed Brexit, no Brexit and the risk of continental-style populist parties. My column:
author: FraserNelson

text: Perhaps this is sentimentality, but the cohesion of a continent is, in no small part, about feeling & shared values. Bonds of trade, travel, marriage and more are strong - and getting stronger. Despite Brexit...
author: FraserNelson

text: I imagine it depends on your definition of Europe. Mine is geographical and cultural, rather than political. A European family of 44 members, not 28. I’ve never thought of Norway as being in any way less European than Sweden, for example.
author: FraserNelson

text: Peston: Why Theresa May might not hold another Brexit vote
author: FraserNelson

text: Britain will always be in the European family. And I'm sure a younger generation of EU leaders will recognise the UK as the EU's greatest single ally.
author: FraserNelson

text: It’s not just the DUP. Some of the most hardened Brexiteers are now swinging behind May’s deal - accepting that they have been snookered. My Telegraph column:
author: FraserNelson

text: Better than 50:50 chance that the government can get the DUP on board for meaningful vote 3, says James Forsyth. If DUP jumps, Mogg will follow.
author: FraserNelson
